metadata.citation: Young, Michael D. 1996. 'Cognitive Mapping Meets Semantic Networks.' The Journal of Conflict Resolution 40(3): 395-414.
metadata.annotation: Enhanced cognitive mapping using semantic networks for representing and analyzing belief structures

classification.summary: A semantic-network-based extension of cognitive mapping that encodes relationships, truth-values, and modifiers for more comprehensive modeling of belief structures.

entities.name: concept
entities.description: A discrete idea or object in the cognitive (semantic) network that can serve as a subject or object in a statement.

connections.description: Represents that two concepts are considered the same or equivalent.
Indicates a conditional statement (e.g., 'if X then Y').
Indicates that one concept is part of another concept.
Represents a comparative preference or ranking, where one concept is preferred over another.
Represents hypothetical or conditional relationships; if one concept occurs, then another follows.
Indicates that one concept is owned or possessed by another.
Represents a positive causal relationship where one concept increases or promotes another concept.
Marks a class-membership or categorical relationship, indicating that the subject is of the type of the object.
Represents that one concept (often a goal) leads to or is used as a means to another aim or outcome.
Represents a negative causal relationship where one concept reduces or hinders another concept.
Represents a relationship in which the subject has knowledge of the object.
Captures the logical or evidentiary basis linking one concept as justification for another.
Specifies that one concept is an attribute or property of another concept.
Specifies the spatial relationship of one concept being located in or at another concept.
Denotes that an actor accepts a proposal, situation, or object.
Denotes that an actor expresses or experiences a feeling or emotion toward another actor or concept.
Denotes that an actor buys or acquires something from another actor or entity.
Denotes that an actor permits another actor or concept to perform some action or exist in some state.
Denotes that an actor shows respect or homage toward another actor or concept.
Denotes the formal approval of a treaty or agreement by an actor.
Denotes that an actor declares or states a position or claim.
Denotes that an actor refrains from acknowledging or responding to another actor or concept.
Denotes that an actor decreases something (e.g., tension, arms, resources).
Denotes an actor helping or aiding another actor or concept.
Denotes that an actor tries to shape or affect another actor’s decisions or a concept’s state.
Denotes that an actor frees or lets go of another actor or object.
Denotes that an actor assaults or aggressively acts against another actor.
Denotes an actor entering into a situation to influence or alter it.
Denotes that an actor brings something back to a prior state or returns it to another actor.
Denotes that an actor brings about an effect or event (often used in a general sense).
Denotes that an actor enters another actor's domain forcibly or aggressively.
Denotes that an actor shares a resource, position, or concept with another actor.
Denotes that an actor no longer retains possession or control of something.
Denotes that an actor directs or guides another actor or initiative.
Denotes that an actor signs a document or agreement (often treaties, contracts).
Denotes that an actor challenges or opposes another actor directly.
Denotes that an actor imposes a restriction or boundary on another actor or concept.
Denotes that an actor causes an action or process to cease.
Denotes that an actor contemplates or regards a concept or possibility.
Denotes that an actor upholds or continues a state or object.
Denotes that an actor provides help or endorsement to another actor or concept.
Denotes that an actor seeks advice or confers with another actor.
Denotes that an actor comes into contact or convenes with another actor.
Denotes that an actor issues a threat or warning to another actor.
Denotes that an actor exercises authority or power over another actor or a concept.
Denotes that an actor observes or watches another actor or concept.
Denotes that an actor applies or employs a resource or concept.
Denotes that two or more actors work together.
Denotes that two or more actors engage in discussion to reach an agreement.
Denotes that an actor checks or confirms the accuracy of something.
Denotes that an actor makes a choice or forms a conclusion.
Denotes that an actor removes barriers or begins something (e.g., negotiations, door, border).
Denotes that an actor travels to meet another actor or attends a location concept.
Denotes that an actor protects or guards another actor or concept from harm.
Denotes that an actor issues a command or directive to another actor.
Denotes that actors formally register a choice regarding a concept or decision.
Denotes that an actor postpones an action or event.
Denotes that an actor arranges or structures a group, event, or concept.
Denotes that an actor removes or pulls back from a situation or location.
Denotes that an actor compels compliance with rules or agreements.
Denotes that an actor carries out or executes a task or role.
Denotes that an actor gives way or surrenders to another actor or an external force.
Denotes that an actor increases or improves something (e.g., capability, relationship).
Denotes that an actor puts forward an idea, plan, or suggestion for others to consider.

properties.description: A label or alternate name used to unify references to the same concept in the network.
A classification or type assignment for a concept (e.g., actor, object, policy).
Frequency or importance assigned to a relationship (how many times it appears)
Indicates the extent to which concepts are organized under a small set of bridges or superordinate ideas
Indicates how interlinked the concepts are (ratio of relationships to total nodes)
Total number of unique concepts in the cognitive map
Extent to which relationships are held with equal strength (standard deviation of salience)
Number of additions, deletions, or salience adjustments required to convert one map to another
Measures differences between two cognitive maps using shared concepts only

modifiers.description: Indicates the relationship or action occurred in the past
Indicates the relationship or action currently holds or is ongoing
Indicates the relationship or action is expected to hold at a future time
Indicates a desired end state or outcome (something the author wants to be true)
Indicates a condition or possibility that may or may not come true (if–then reasoning)
Indicates a sense of obligation, ideal, or moral preference (states what should or ought to be)
Connects two or more items in a joint statement (e.g., subjects performing a joint action)
Connects two or more items in an alternative set (e.g., possible choices)
Indicates the statement applies to the entire set of instances
Indicates the statement applies to no instances of the set
Indicates the statement applies to at least one instance but not necessarily all
Indicates the statement does not apply to every instance of the set

metrics.description: Measures the vertical organization of concepts based on how many relationships are “bridges.” A bridge is a unique path to a concept. Higher dependency indicates fewer lateral (horizontal) connections between concepts/relationships.
metrics.interpretation: Values near 1 indicate a single primary chain or superordinate concept from which most subordinate beliefs derive; values near 0 indicate less hierarchical dependence.

metrics.description: Indicates how interrelated the concepts are in the map. Higher connectedness means more internal linkages among concepts.
metrics.interpretation: Values approach 1 if relationships predominate over concepts; values near 0 suggest very loose or minimal connectivity.

metrics.description: Counts all unique concept nodes in a cognitive map. Larger size usually corresponds to greater content breadth or expertise in a given domain.
metrics.formula: Number of concepts in map G.
metrics.interpretation: A straightforward measure of scope or domain coverage in the belief structure.

metrics.description: Measures how evenly beliefs are emphasized/supported. Each relationship’s salience is how often that belief reappears in the text.
metrics.formula: Standard deviation of relationship salience across the map.
metrics.interpretation: Zero standard deviation means all beliefs have the same salience; higher standard deviation implies a few dominant or strongly held beliefs stand out.

metrics.description: Identifies overlapping concepts, conflicting or differing connections, and unique areas in each map.
metrics.formula: Qualitative check for concepts and relationships shared or missing between two maps (no numerical formula).
metrics.interpretation: Used to isolate the specific differences or commonalities in beliefs, enabling targeted analysis of misperceptions or shifts in meaning.

metrics.description: Analogous to string-edit distance, measuring the total discrete changes needed for one map to replicate another map fully.
metrics.formula: Minimum number of concept-additions, concept-deletions, relationship-additions, relationship-deletions, or salience changes to convert map A into map B.
metrics.interpretation: Higher cost indicates more content or structural dissimilarities, suggesting greater cognitive work for an individual adjusting to a new belief set.

metrics.description: Captures discrepancies specifically in overlapping areas of two cognitive maps, ignoring concepts that are not shared.
metrics.formula: Focuses on shared concepts: total relationship changes (additions, deletions, salience changes) for the overlap of map A and B.
metrics.interpretation: Zero indicates identical shared structures; higher values denote greater divergence of beliefs on the same topics.

steps.objective: Capture a rich representation of beliefs, preserving nuances such as tense, conditionals, negations, and frequency of repetition.
steps.completion_criteria: All relevant text passages are coded into structured data statements with high inter-coder reliability.

steps.stage_name: Differentiate Relationships and Apply Coding Categories
steps.objective: Retain richer meaning from the text while moving beyond binary cause–effect representations.
steps.completion_criteria: Relationship annotations accurately reflect intended meaning in the source text, including temporal and modal information.

steps.stage_name: Represent Belief Structures as Semantic Networks
steps.objective: Produce a manipulable knowledge structure that accommodates compound statements, multiple relationship types, and future reasoning or modeling needs.
steps.completion_criteria: All coded statements merge into a single structured network, with unique nodes linked by labeled relationships.

steps.stage_name: Aggregate Multiple Sources and Resolve Synonyms
steps.objective: Generate a composite map of beliefs across time or text sources, allowing consistent references to the same ideas using a single node.
steps.completion_criteria: All overlapping/identical concepts are merged appropriately, ensuring a coherent and consolidated network.

steps.objective: Gain insights into map complexity, level of integration, shifts in emphasis, or restructuring of beliefs over time or across sources.
steps.completion_criteria: Quantitative measures are computed without error, and results can be plausibly interpreted alongside qualitative evidence.

Telos.success_criteria: Accurate representation and analysis of belief structures, enabling systematic comparison and insights into how cognitive maps change over time or differ among actors.
